job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Williamsburg, VA

review_title: Great college, not a fun department
pros: the work feels good - you are helping students every day. The work life balance is definitely achievable - easy to put in a solid 8-9 hour workday, and then leave it behind for the most part (special events etc not included but...). no guilt about vacations etc.
cons: The culture in that office was toxic. The leadership encouraged distrust and There was no real appreciation for what people did. The leadership played favorites and would seemingly select at least one person to harass at a time and then just rotate around - everyone tries to stay out of the firing line, so no one can appear to like anyone else or you end up in the firing line when that person does. The upper management (President, VP's) all must know yet nothing is done. Multiple complints have been filed, and leadership is simply promoted.

review_title: Not like many elite institutions - cordial atmosphere
pros: - located in beautiful Williamsburg - 5 weeks vacation - supervisors who work diligently alongside staff - students are very polite and intelligent - faculty are not as intense with professional staff as they are at some other universities I have worked at
cons: - pay is low for certain positions but work load is high - students are bright but severely anxious about so many small matters....they create so much work for themselves and staff - state systems are overly laborious - on boarding- with HR can be overwhelming so many forms to fill out and platforms and training to interact with in the first month. -bureaucracy, especially in terms of anything financial is insane

pros: - Flexibility - Community Feel - Large focus on undergrads
cons: There are not a lot of opportunities to get a promotion or advance the career. Large focus on undergrads

review_title: Rewarding with decent pay, minimal advancement opportunities

cons: As an adjunct with an only masters degree, there are minimal opportunities for a full time teaching load making this only a part time job.

pros: There are a wonderful set of colleagues.

review_title: Terrible Pay but Good Working Conditions

W&M is a high cost of living area and they are paying GAs $5 an hour. They also prohibit you from working more than 9 hours of an outside job to make up for your expenses.

The hours are quite flexible and your academics are always understood to be a higher priority than work. Great way to give back to the school community as well by helping support faculty and peers.
cons: Training is quite minimal so a lot of the job involves asking somebody more informed about the issue a particular client may be having, essentially just forwarding issues rather than always having the opportunity to provide solutions.

review_title: Lower level employees not treated with respect
pros: If you get a good manager and don't expect much growth, you can find a decent job here. State benefits
cons: Sadly, many departments have poor middle management and very little opportunity for growth or development. Many departments run unchecked with toxic workplace environments and taking advantage of employees.

pros: As a whole, the Division staff are enthusiastic, dedicated, extremely hard working.  Collegial across departments.  Leadership works hard to keep all of us abreast of what is going on throughout the division.  Great winter break party this year.  The College gives us all the State holidays that we have to work during the year back to us during Winter Break, which gives us around 10 days off between semesters; very nice. Great medical benefits; so-so dental benefits. Generous vacation allowance, although I'm not sure that that is distributed evenly across all staff.
cons: The State regularly suspends pay raises for 2-3 years at a time in times of financial stress.  It is unclear why a pay raise is awarded when it does occur. The State of Virginia makes permanent cuts in W&M budget every year or two, with systemic repercussions:  Limited opportunities for advancement.  Professional development happens unevenly across the departments.  Work/Life balance is not valued, subtly discouraged, as we all try to do more and more with less and less.

review_title: Great History, Awesome Potential, Soured Culture
pros: W&M is a fantastic institution and fabulous for students and most faculty--especially young professors seeking their tenure.  The surroundings are beautiful and serene.  Ideal small school and loads of untapped potential.
cons: The problems lie mostly with the administration and staff due to two major factors:  budget and location.  Finding excellent staff requires either the cash to pay them well (which this state school simply does not have), or a place so desirable that they overlook the meager pay (which, unfortunately, the area does not provide).  This all leads to a poisonous culture of infighting and gossip, exacerbating the issues.

review_title: Graduate Research Positions -- Not about the money.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Williamsburg, VA
pros: I am a graduate student in a doctoral program.  Clearly this is not a permanent job, so the standards of  comparison are not the same as other jobs. However, the track record of students graduating with doctorate degrees and starting new jobs is quite good.  Even students who decide not to complete the degree have been able to leave move on to lucrative positions based on the work they have completed at the College.
cons: Some people like the location.  I am not a fan.  In addition, there is a stipend associated with my position, so performing no work or working like crazy are rewarded the same.

pros:
-State retirement. 
-Low-quality expectation.
-significant amount of leave
cons:
- Low pay and any raise is tiny (if you ever get one)
- It's almost impossible to move up in the ranks*.

*There is a significant amount of discrimination that takes place. You must be related to someone or a (female or minority ) to move forward in IT.  Cronyism is rampant, and unless you are very close to the right person or are related to the right person good luck!

review_title: Great school, great people, but low grad-student pay
pros:
-Intelligent, driven colleagues (both fellow students and professors)
-Friendly environment that encourages you to push yourself without overdoing it
-Good work-school-life balance relative to other graduate schools
-Beautiful surroundings
-Pretty good reputation / name recognition (depending on field)
-Some professional graduate programs pay stipend
cons:
-Low pay relative to many other graduate programs
-Williamsburg is underwhelming if you aren't a tourist

review_title: Important Educational Mission, but Pervasive Morale Issues
pros:
There is amazing academic and educational work being done at William and Mary.
Many of the students and faculty are really wonderful, engaged, interesting people.
Lots of committees (faculty) and student groups demonstrate a community focus.
Beautiful campus.
Perks in some cases, like your spouse being able to get a cheap gym membership or free/reduced cost tuition.
cons:
I've had a lot of problems with getting my Human Resources and Payroll issues sorted out. There have been a lot of changes in the last couples years regarding which forms and protocols to use, and when it turns out you are using an outdated method, some administrative technicians are accusatory instead of helpful.

HR and Payroll are particularly hostile when you are a student employee, they treat you like you are completely untrustworthy and unreliable (particularly the case if you are a graduate student who is in a substantial job at the College).

William and Mary has been squeezing the housekeeping staff increasingly over the last year, there have been management changes and housekeepers are literally told they only have 12 minutes to mop a hallway, or whatever. It makes them feel like cogs in a machine, and has been terrible for morale. It's also not very nice to work in an environment where not everyone is treated humanely.

William and Mary has been on a salary freeze for a long time now, with a few minimal adjustments. Employees at all levels are underpaid.

Works like a large state bureaucracy - jobs can take 4-5 weeks to be finalized, paperwork abounds, lots of restrictions and hoops about how to spend departmental funds.

review_title: A mixed bag - but worth it in the end
pros: Incredible benefits, responsibilities as described in your job, generous vacation time for professional faculty.  Dedicated personnel can be found in most departments.
cons: Basement-level salaries in most areas, lack of advancement opportunities, administrative inertia/inefficiency, inconsistent performance assessment standards.

pros: Fun interacting with kids and the job is pretty easy going. You're mainly helping out the kids as they work on various STEM activities. You're serving as a leader and enhancing their learning experience.
cons: Don't really have any cons. The job was pretty fun and it's great to see the kids have fun and learning.

pros:
People
Work
Flexibility
Relaxed Environment
Beautiful Campus
Department Events
Catered Food
cons: Politics was becoming an issue when I left. Intersectionalism played an important role with people who were more qualified workers, being forced out for younger-check more boxes- people.  Management "listened" to workers, but nothing more than a mere ploy to appease the employees, as their final word was law.

review_title: Outstanding undergraduates, grads are a mix, administration and colleagues not as supportive as they should be.
pros: Some great undergraduate students.  Graduate programs are a mix -- some are strong, others geared toward local students.  Some departments are dysfunctional, like any place.  The institution has been through rough times, may be on upswing again.  Great President, other administration is a mix.
cons: Housing costs are sky high.  Values of institution are at times suspect when they bring strippers and pics of naked children to campus and call it art.

pros: William & Mary offers excellent benefits.  They pay a large portion (+- 80%) of the health insurance premiums.  Employees are enrolled in the Virginia Retirement System and are offered matching 401k or IRA accounts.  The pay is competitive for the area and there are a number of paid holidays.
cons: Coming from a small business it took some time to get used to all of the forms and procedures that are required in a larger organization.

pros: Opportunity for more interaction with some amazing professors.  Strengthen knowledge of course material.  Teaching and helping students.  Credibility of having been a TA at a good university - even better if you can do it as an undergrad.
cons: Grading and correcting technical assignments. Extra work when you have the least time - exams to grade while you're studying for exams.

job_title: Assistant Director, Development in Williamsburg, VA
pros: Work was rewarding, coworkers were enjoyable, I was relatively flexible. TONS of vacation time. Seriously tons. Working with undergrads is great - they're smart and self-reliant, so they make excellent employees. Life is more laid-back in a small town like Williamsburg.
cons: Pay wasn't that high in Williamsburg. The state controls everything, so raises are hard to come by. In terms of hours, unless you have a special case there's generally the expectation that you work 8 to 5.

review_title: TA: Responsibilities include laboratory or lecture assistant for introductory or upper-level courses in the sciences.
pros:
* Instruct mid and upper-level courses to some of the brightest undergraduate students in the nation. 

* Course modules are dynamic and flexible, and often incorporate research findings from the frontiers of science. 

* Graduate research opportunities are almost always completely funded
cons:
* Small research university
* Moderate to low funding for research labs

pros: Students are great - appreciative of all you do.  Work life balance is good - appreciate being able to attend my children's school events,etc.
cons: Important to get your compensation negotiated high before you come into the state system. Once you are in it takes multiple jumps in position and grade to get the salary you should be earning for the job responsibilities.

pros: Wonderful benefits, plenty of time off, laid back atmosphere, casual on most levels, great to interact and mentor students
cons: Too many meetings, too many committees, slow in implementing change, most departments are short staffed due to limited budgets, but processes are not simplified to reflect the levels of staffing and issues are handled slowly

review_title: Working Hard to be the best public Ivy.
pros: The College has a great mix of undergraduates, graduate students, faculty, and staff that are all passionate about pushing the College to be the best version of itself.
cons: Small town, and a coterie of small minded people, that want to keep the College mired in tradition, no matter the cost.

pros: Working with students is fantastic - very diverse community.
cons: The financial system is a mess. The travel process means you need to pay upfront and then be reimbursed, which can be really frustrating. If our staff could travel more, we would be more successful at our jobs.

review_title: Misrepresentation of Benefits during  Recruitment,  Micromanagement, Subsequent Termination
pros: There are no pros to working here.
cons:
After working on a part time and full time basis at the Schroeder Center for Health Policy for the previous 3 years, I would strongly discourage anyone from seeking employment there. 

Prior to my last position as a Research Associate , I had worked there as a research assistant, a research fellow and a graduate assistant on temporary and part time statuses. Until then I had no complaints regarding my work and was named one of the "Outstanding Graduate Assistants" in 2016. The director of the Schroeder Center contacted me directly in June, 2017 to inform me of an upcoming grant and open position. During the phone call describing the position, she used the phrase "I can write the position for you." During subsequent (verbal) conversations she indicated that an employee benefit of the position would be the ability to take one class per semester at the College with waived tuition. In January, 2018 she denied my request to take a class in the Mathematics department, stating that it would interfere with my working schedule. Furthermore, I received additional communication from W&M Human Resources that this benefit was restricted to those who had continuous Virginia residency for 2 years. 

Had the residency requirement been made publicly available anywhere on the W&M website, I would not have taken the position, as I had already interrupted my class schedule at the Harvard Extension School which was paid for by my previous employer. 

Subsequent performance reviews to HR included remarks about the frequency of using the restroom (and I quote, "sometimes leaving his desk twice in one hour"), and then stated one instance of excusing myself during a two hour meeting as a failure to meet job performance standards. Advice on how to improve performance was limited to "searching the Stata User guide" and to "follow my instructions to the letter." During the last two months of my employment, I consistently sought feedback on work and was given inconsistent responses. 

On May 31st, 2018, I was terminated from my position at the Schroeder Center for Health Policy at William & Mary, with no severance and requiring the continuation of $778 in COBRA payments to continue my insurance coverage. Human Resources was incredibly unhelpful during this process, first stating that I would receive *no* coverage during the month of June, only to later state that I would receive retroactive coverage. 

To summarize, the director of the Schroeder Center has been condescending, micromanaging, and manipulative during both the interview process and my subsequent employment.

pros: Plush, well-funded small liberal arts college. They treat employees well and have good research facilities. You will always have top notch researchers and teachers to interact with.
cons: Powerful personalities can destroy departments. The upper administration could have put a stop to these issues, but lack of leadership caused it to spread like a cancer.
